definition:
Given an integer $m$ consisting of $k$ digits $d_1, \dots, d_k$ in base
$b$, let $$j = \sum_{i = 1}^{k} d_i,$$ then repeat this operation on the
digits of $j$ until $j < b$. This stores in $j$ the [*digital root*]{}
of $m$. The number of iterations of the sum operation is called the
[*additive persistence*]{} of $m$.

The digital root of $b^x$ is always 1 for any natural $x$, while the
digital root of $yb^n$ (where $y$ is another natural number) is the same
as the digital root of $y$. This should not be taken to imply that the
digital root is necessarily a multiplicative function.

The digital root of an integer of the form $n(b - 1)$ is always $b - 1$.

Another way to calculate the digital root for $m > b$ is with the
formula $m - (b - 1)\lfloor {{m - 1} \over {b - 1}} \rfloor$.
